p.s: In the following I'm going to comment on Brian Pollard's statement that [...] in the twenty-first century the situation has changed, workers are not being exploited by employers, now employers are being exploited by employees and why I very much disagree with him.
While it may be true that this applies to some unions as they are a lot about workers rights I don't think you can generalize it as he does connecting it to the economic mess of the whole world.

I think the biggest problem is capatalismcapitalism, so how the capital is shared around the world, because many rich companyscompanies take advantage of that situation as they abuse people in poor, foreign countries.
So we still have the same situation of employers exploiting their workers by not caring about their health and paying them very little.

The situation might have turned around in richer countries as people have a chance to have an impact but in countries like Bangladesh many workers they need every little money and are not willing to risk their life for a fair job.
And that's werewhere globalisation increases that problem.
Because as Brian Pollard states, the prices of fair produced goods simply can't compete with the ones made in harsh conditions.
People in for example Germany, like us, just don't want to spend a lot of money.
That's why I think we need to stop buying from brands producing in such conditions, like Nike and Adidas.
By that you would pressure them into change.
Some people would argue, that it destroys their living base but I think this kind of pressure is needed as they already work in slave like conditions and brands would have to react fast.
All in all I think the main problem is still employers exploiting their workers, which is why we need to be more careful about what we buy in order to make change.
